saberes: Block 1. Communication
▪ Strategies for the acquisition of self-confidence in the use of the foreign language.
▪ Learning techniques.
▪ The treatment of errors as an integral part of the learning process and their acceptance as an opportunity for improvement.
▪ Basic strategies of common use for the comprehension and production of oral texts; written and multimodal, brief, simple and contextualized texts.

▪ Basic communicative functions of common use appropriate to the field and context: greet, say goodbye, introduce and introduce oneself; describe people, objects and places in a patterned manner; request and exchange information on daily issues; express routines in a guided way; give directions and elementary instructions; express time, quantity and space.

▪ Contextual models and basic discursive genres commonly used in the comprehension, production and co-production of oral, written and multimodal, short and simple, literary and non-literary texts of various types, such as brochures, instructions, standards, notices or regulatory conversation of coexistence (thank you, apologize, ask for permission).

▪ Elementary linguistic units and meanings associated with them, such as expression of the entity and its properties, quantity and number; space and spatial relations; affirmation, exclamation, negation, question.
▪ Elementary vocabulary related to close personal relationships, housing, places and environments of interest.
▪ Basic sound, stress and intonation patterns in common use, and general communicative functions associated with these patterns.

▪ Basic orthographic conventions in common use and meanings associated with formats and graphic elements (punctuation marks, acronyms, symbols). Basic conversation conventions and strategies in common use face-to-face and simultaneously, or through other means, to initiate, maintain and end the communication, take and give the floor and ask for and give directions.
▪ Resources for learning and elementary strategies for guided information search in analog and digital media.

▪ Commonly used basic analog and digital tools for oral, written, and multimodal comprehension, production, and co-production; and virtual platforms for educational interaction, cooperation, and collaboration.
▪ Elementary resources, skills, attitudes and situations that allow one to initiate linguistic mediation activities in basic everyday situations.
Block 2. Plurilingualism

▪ Basic strategies in common use to identify, retain, recover and use linguistic units (lexicon, similar phonemes, morphosyntax, sound patterns, position of question marks and exclamation marks) from the comparison of the languages that make up the linguistic repertoire staff.

▪ Strategies and techniques to compensate for communication deficiencies to respond to an elementary need, despite the limitations derived from the level of competence in the foreign language and in the other languages of the own linguistic repertoire.
▪ Basic strategies and tools for self-assessment and peer-assessment, analogue and digital, individual and collective.
Block 3. Interculturality
▪ Communication and relationship with people from other countries through the foreign language: different cultures and ways of life.
▪ Participation in planned communicative exchanges, with students of the foreign language, through different means.
▪ Elementary cultural patterns transmitted through the uses of the foreign language.
▪ Most representative elementary sociocultural and sociolinguistic aspects related to customs, daily life and basic interpersonal relationships in countries where the foreign language is spoken.
▪ Basic strategies of common use to understand and appreciate linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity, taking into account ecosocial and democratic values.
▪ Initiation in the basic strategies for detecting discriminatory uses of verbal and non-verbal language.
criteriosEvaluacion: CE1.1. Recognize and interpret the global meaning and also words and phrases previously presented in short and simple oral, written and multimodal texts of various types, on frequent, daily topics, of personal relevance and close to the experience of the students, appropriate to the level of development and expressed in a comprehensible, clear manner and in standard language through different supports. OBJ1

CE1.2. Select and apply, in a guided way, suitable strategies in everyday communicative situations that are relevant to students, to capture the global meaning and process explicit information in short and simple texts on familiar topics. OBJ1

CE1.3. Orally express short sentences with basic information about everyday matters and relevant to students, following models and using verbal and non-verbal resources in a guided way, paying attention to rhythm, stress and intonation. OBJ2

CE1.4. Write very short and simple words and phrases, appropriate to the proposed communicative situation, based on models and through analog and digital tools, using elementary structures and lexicon, on everyday matters and of personal relevance for the students .OBJ2

CE1.5. Select and apply strategies in a guided way to produce brief, useful and simple messages, appropriate to the communicative intentions, using, with help, resources and physical or digital supports depending on the needs of each moment. OBJ2

CE1.6. Participate in interactive and simple situations of brief exchanges of information on daily topics, of personal relevance and close to their experience, previously prepared, relying on resources such as repetition, slow pace or non-verbal language, and showing empathy and respect for linguistic courtesy. OBJ3
CE1.7. Select and use, in a guided way and in everyday situations, elementary strategies to greet, say goodbye and introduce oneself; express short messages; and ask and answer simple questions. OBJ3

CE1.8. Interpret and explain basic information in a guided way, helping with comprehension difficulties, with empathy and interest in the interlocutors, relying on various resources and supports. OBJ4
CE2.1. Compare and contrast the similarities and differences between different languages reflecting, in a guided way, on basic aspects of how they work. OBJ5

CE2.2. Use and differentiate the knowledge and strategies to improve their own ability to communicate and learn the foreign language, guided and with the support of other participants and analog and digital media. OBJ5

CE2.3. Record and apply, in a guided manner, the elementary progress and difficulties in the foreign language learning process, participating in self-assessment and peer-assessment activities, such as those proposed in the European Language Portfolio (PEL). OBJ5

CE3.1. Act with respect in intercultural situations, identifying and comparing elementary similarities and differences between languages and cultures, and showing rejection of discrimination, prejudice and stereotypes of any kind in everyday and habitual communicative contexts. OBJ6

CE3.2. Recognize and appreciate the linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity typical of countries where the foreign language is spoken as a source of personal enrichment, showing interest in understanding basic and habitual cultural and linguistic elements that promote peaceful coexistence and respect for the others.OBJ6
